attributes.title: Hostility and Immigrant Political Integration: Understanding the Muslim Experience in Western Europe

q1.value: Hostility and Immigrant Political Integration: Understanding the Muslim Experience in Western Europe

q8.value: Registration after researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The purpose of this project is to examine how hostility by native-majorities affects the political attitudes and behaviors of targeted immigrant-minority groups. Currently, the relationship between native-majority behaviors and immigrant-minority political activity is understudied. My own project aims to account for this by better understanding how native hostility influences these outcomes. In doing so, I intend to better account for how the environment in which immigrant-minorities are received and socialized matters for their political decision-making. My research question asks: under what conditions do Muslim immigrant-minorities engage in political activity? I focus on both formal and informal (i.e., activity within and external to the political system, respectively) activities to examine how political hostility might shape political outcomes. To address the absence of data and test my hypotheses on the attitudes and political decisions of European MIM groups, I field my own survey of MIMs in the United Kingdom. In this survey, I implement a priming experiment to vary the experience of anti-Muslim hostility among respondents. I hypothesize that perceptions of hostility will affect respondents’ decisions to participate in political activity. Specifically, I hypothesize that these perceptions will lead MIMs to approach their vote choice through an in-group-oriented lens. I also hypothesize that these perceptions will lead MIMs to more likely volunteer in in-group-oriented organizations. I further hypothesize that these decisions will be moderated by respondents’ attachment to their Muslim group identity, which has become politicized in contemporary politics.

q16.value: H1a: MIMs who hold higher group identity attachment will be more likely to vote conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H1b: MIMs who politically identify with more pro-group parties will be more likely to vote conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H1c: MIMs who do not politically identify with any party will be less likely to vote conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H2a: MIMs who hold higher group identity attachment will be more likely to favor both pro-group parties and group-specific issues conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H2b: MIMs who hold higher group identity attachment will be less likely to favor hostile parties conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H2c: MIMs who hold political ideologies that are not in conflict (with pro-group agendas and parties) such as non-identifiers and group-friendly party identifiers will be more likely to support pro-group agendas and parties conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H2d: MIMs who do not politically identify with any party will be less likely to favor any parties conditional on exposure to group-based hostility. H3: MIMs who hold higher group identity attachment will be more likely to participate in in-group-oriented organizations conditional on exposure to group-based hostility.

q17.value: To test my hypotheses I prime exposure to group-targeted political hostility in an original survey design. For the original survey, the treatment will test for the effects of political hostility at the group level. The prime will discuss hostility performed by those in power that targets social groups regardless of individuals’ personal group membership. This means that I will not prime for hostility that is individually-targeted or socially-sourced. I also include two control conditions to ensure that it is not simply the mention of politics (Control 1) or Muslims (Control 2), that is doing the work of priming a sense of group threat. To test for this, I pose two more neutral discussions as alternatives to the political hostility treatment. Hypotheses are then tested on my outcomes of interest using basic regression analysis (OLS or logit where necessary).

attributes.title: Institutional Effects on the Perception of Gender Bias in Judicial Selection

q1.value: Institutional Effects on the Perception of Gender Bias in Judicial Selection

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Standards of descriptive representation are increasingly applied to the judiciary, but little is known about the processes through which citizens (1) come to believe that judicial selection procedures are gender fair or gender biased and (2) hold those responsible for bias accountable. In this project I use evidence from two survey experiments to test how prior beliefs about the fairness of merit/commission assisted selection versus gubernatorial selection procedures affect whether and how respondents perceive gender disparity as bias. In addition, I test how citizens attribute blame for perceived bias across institutions. I hypothesize (1) that respondents' believe (a priori) that merit/commission selection procedures are more fair relative to gubernatorial selection procedures; (2) that the belief in the fairness of merit selection procedures does not depend on the term "merit" in the label; (3) that respondents will be less likely to perceive gender disparity on the bench as evidence of bias under merit selection procedures relative to gubernatorial selection procedures; (4) that the difference in perceptions of bias between merit and gubernatorial selection procedures will be greatest at token levels of diversity; and (5) that blame attribution for perceived bias will be more diffuse under merit selection than gubernatorial selection.

q16.value: H1: Respondents will perceive merit selection procedures are more fair than gubernatorial selection procedures. H1b: Respondents' preferences for merit selection procedures over gubernatorial selection procedures are not due to the term ``merit'' in the label. H2: Respondents will be less likely to interpret gender disparity on the bench as evidence of bias under merit selection procedures than under gubernatorial selection procedures. H3: Differences in perceptions of bias under merit and gubernatorial selection procedures should be greatest at token levels of gender diversity (one woman on the bench). H4: Among those who perceive bias in selection, respondents will blame the governor under gubernatorial selection procedures and respondents will split blame among the governor and the merit commission under merit commission selection procedures.

q17.value: I will test the above hypotheses with data from two survey experiments. Both survey's will be fielded through Amazon's Mechanical Turk, and analysis will be restricted to respondents who live in the United States. Respondents will be randomly assigned to treatment groups, and I will collect demographic information to test balance across treatment and control groups. First survey Experiment: To test whether respondents perceive merit selection as more fair than gubernatorial selection, I describe each method to respondents briefly. Then, I ask respondents which method they think is more fair. To identify whether respondents' beliefs about the fairness of merit selection procedures depend on the term ``merit,'' I give a treatment group the same information and ask the same questions, but I replace the term ``merit selection'' with ``commission assisted selection.'' If responses are the same across treatment groups, then respondents preferences for or against ``merit selection'' are not due to the term ``merit'' in the name. As a manipulation/attention check. Respondents will be asked to select which institutions they were asked to compare from a list. Analysis H1: To test whether respondents believe merit selection procedures are more (or less) fair than gubernatorial selection, I will compare the proportion of respondents who select gubernatorial selection as more fair to the proportion of respondents who select merit selection as more fair. Analysis H1b: To test whether respondents' beliefs about the fairness of merit selection procedures depend on the term "merit,'' I will compare the proportion of respondents in each treatment group who do not select gubernatorial selection procedures as more fair. If the proportions are the same across groups who saw "merit selection'' and "commission assisted selection,'' then the perception of fairness of these selection systems is not due to the label "merit.'' In contrast, if more respondents perceive "merit selection'' as fair than those who saw "commission assisted selection,'' then we can conclude that the label "merit'' does affect perceptions of fairness. Second Survey Experiment: For the second survey experiment, respondents are randomly assigned to a selection procedure, either gubernatorial selection or merit selection. They will read information about how the selection procedure works. Then, they will be showed information about 7 judges on the court. The number of women on the court will vary across groups. Respondents will be asked -- based on the outcome of selection -- whether they believe the selection process was fair. Those who indicate that the process is unfair will be asked to explain why and they will be asked to indicate who or what they believe is responsible for the unfairness. There are two treatment variables -- the selection procedure and the number of women -- for a total of six treatment groups. For each level of gender diversity, the proportion of respondents who indicate that the process is unfair will be compared across selection institutions. The expectation is that more respondents will perceive the process as fair under merit selection procedures than under gubernatorial selection procedures (H2). In addition, the difference in perceptions of fairness between merit and gubernatorial selection should be greatest at token levels of diversity (H3). Finally, among those who indicate the process appears unfair, under gubernatorial selection procedures, blame should be consolidated on the governor; under merit selection, blame should be split between the governor and the commission (H4). As a manipulation check, respondents will be asked at the end of the survey how many women were on the court. Analysis H2: I will compare the proportion of respondents who indicate "definitely unfair'' and ``probably unfair'' across institutional treatments at each level of diversity using a simple difference-in-proportions test. The expectation is that respondents in the merit commission treatment group will be less likely to indicate definitely or probably unfair than those in the gubernatorial selection group (H2). Analysis H3: The difference in perceptions of bias between gubernatorial and merit selection should be greatest among respondents who observed one woman on the bench (H3). To test this hypothesis, I will compare the difference in proportions between gubernatorial and merit selection across levels of diversity. Analysis H4: To test whether the presence of multiple actors obscures blame attribution, I will compare the proportion of respondents who blame the governor across both selection institutions. It may be that the governor is blamed for disparate selections regardless of the presence of a selection commission. However, the expectation is that respondents in the merit selection treatment group will split blame between the governor and the merit commission. I will use difference in proportions tests. Because I making multiple comparisons within a sample, I will report the Bonferroni corrected p-values.

It may be that the governor is blamed for disparate selections regardless of the presence of a selection commission. However, the expectation is that respondents in the merit selection treatment group will split blame between the governor and the merit commission. I will use difference in proportions tests. Because I making multiple comparisons within a sample, I will report the Bonferroni corrected p-values.

attributes.title: Local Partners for Local Problems: When Does Foreign Security Assistance Undermine Public Support for Local Combatants?

q1.value: Local Partners for Local Problems: When Does Foreign Security Assistance Undermine Public Support for Local Combatants?

q5.value: The author would like to thank the U.S. Institute of Peace for their generous dissertation fellowship support for this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: How does foreign security assistance affect civilian support for local combatants in fragile states? Can external statebuilders build the capacity of local security providers without undermining the perceived legitimacy of these groups in the eyes of the civilian population? This projects investigates how foreign security assistance affects civilian attitudes toward local combatants. Specifically, I am interested in how the attributes of the foreign security assistance -- including the identity of the external statebuilder and local client, as well as the specific means of security assistance -- affect public perceptions of legitimacy for local combatants. Toward that end, I focus on building and operationalizing concepts for measuring combatant support with the goal of better understanding what it means for local security providers to be viewed as legitimate by the general public. The empirical cornerstone of this project is an original survey experiment in Baghdad, where I leverage a series of embedded experiments to investigate how variation in external assistance shapes Iraqi attitudes toward local combatants. This pre-analysis plan includes a provisional theory and hypotheses, resign design, and analysis plan for implementing the survey experiment in the field.

q16.value: This project investigates Iraqi civilian attitudes toward local security providers participating in the anti-ISIL coalition. The goal is to understand how security force assistance provided by an external patron affects public perceptions of legitimacy for local combatants. As such, I test a series of hypotheses looking at the relationship between effective security provision and public perceptions of legitimacy. On the one hand, I test hypotheses related to the "buying hearts and minds" school of counterinsurgency, namely, that security institutions that perform effectively will be perceived of as legitimate by noncombatants. Under this scope of conditions, local combatants that receive external assistance should receive higher levels of public support than their less-effective counterparts. Second, I test hypotheses related to the ethno-sectarian identity of combats and civilians. Here I predict ethno-sectarian differences between clients and patrons, as well as an actor's past exposure to political violence, will result in lower levels of support for security assistance to out-group combatants.

q17.value: The proposed hypotheses will be tested using a survey with three embedded experiments, including an endorsement experiment, conjoint analysis, and an identity-priming vignettes. The endorsement experiments manipulate which foreign country is providing security assistance (and in what form) to the anti-ISIL coalition. The conjoint analysis, in turn, manipulates three critical attributes of security assistance in Iraq: the identity of the foreign patron, the specific means of assistance, and the identity of the local client. Finally, the identity-priming vignettes will examine differences in attribution bias by manipulating the military performance of the coalition, as well as whether local combatants were provided with security assistance from the U.S. military. The interviews will be completed in Baghdad, Iraq, by IACSS (a locally-based market research firm).

q27.value: Independent Incorporate for Administration and Civil Society Studies (IACSS)

attributes.title: Increasing Household Electrification Rates in Rural Uttar Pradesh with Connection Campaigns

q1.value: Increasing Household Electrification Rates in Rural Uttar Pradesh with Connection Campaigns

q2.value: Brian Blankenship | Ryan Kennedy | Jason Chun Yu Wong

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The primary motivation of this project is to evaluate the capacity for social workers to encourage electri cation as a method for meeting the government's goal of 24x7 power to all households in UP by 2019. The electri cation of villages in rural Uttar Pradesh has proceeded rapidly in recent years, but the level of consumption has remained well below the national average (India Ministry of Power, 2017). One of the largest hurdles to increasing consumption is that, even in electri ed villages, many households still lack domestic connections. A large part of the success or failure of the government's ambitious goal of providing 24x7 power to households by 2019 is increasing these household connection rates.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1 Individuals who are exposed to the electri cation campaign will be more likely to submit applications for electricity connections than those not exposed. Hypothesis 2 Individuals who are exposed to the electri cation campaign will be more likely to receive electricity connections than those not exposed. Hypothesis 3 Exposure to an electri cation campaign decrease the perceived diculty of application for electricity access. Hypothesis 4 Exposure to an electri cation campaign will decrease perceived cost of application for electricity access. Hypothesis 5 Exposure to an electrification campaign will have an especially large effect on the probability of submitting applications for electricity connections in households where the head of household has higher levels of trust.

q17.value: Of the 200 habitations that meet our criterion (see pre-analysis plan), 100 will be assigned to the treatment and 100 to the control condition. These will be determined by block-randomization by electricity feeder. 10 household will be surveyed in each habitation. A baseline survey will be administered and the treatment will be given to households in the treatment habitations. They will then be asked if they would like to sign up for an electricity connection. Research team will follow up within two weeks to collect applications and deliver them to the power house. This all will be followed by two endline surveys to determine if an application was submitted and if a connection was established.

q27.value: Morsel Research and Development (overseen by researchers)

attributes.title: Recognizing Good Governance: A Field Experiment in Uganda

q1.value: Recognizing Good Governance: A Field Experiment in Uganda

q2.value: Mark Buntaine | Brigham Daniels | Tanner Bangerter

q5.value: We acknowledge the British Department for International Development for its support of this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We theorize that fostering collective pride in good governance and providing positive recognition for local leaders who forego corruption and work diligently to manage local projects will decrease corruption in a national park revenue-sharing program in western Uganda. We will implement a randomized field experiment and linked ethnographic field study to test whether offering community recognition for the successful planning and implementation of revenue-sharing projects, along with associated radio announcements and public ceremonies that praise good governance, will result in more equitable planning and better delivery of revenue-sharing projects. Our study thus departs from the dominant lines of research on corruption that focus on detection and punishment and instead asks how civic expectations can be realigned to counteract corruption at the local level. We compare outcomes in villages that are made experimentally eligible for positive recognition to those villages that do not have eligibility for recognition.

q16.value: Our hypotheses are: Eligibility for recognition will cause committees to exert more effort and diligence in managing revenue sharing projects. Eligibility for recognition will increase the successful delivery of revenue-sharing projects. Eligibility for recognition will change residents’ norms and expectations to be less accepting of corruption and mismanagement. Eligibility for recognition will change committee members’ norms and beliefs about corruption and mismanagement. More detailed information can be found in our pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We will use a randomized-control trial and accompanying ethnographic work of a research partner to test these hypotheses. As for the randomized control trial, the intervention is described below: Baseline All combination project management committee (PMC) / community procurement committee (CPC) will be provided with a checklist of procedures for considering bids for projects, evaluating the bids, and managing contractors. All combination committees will be trained in the procedures that would be required to earn excellence in revenue sharing. Intervention We propose that each combination project management committee (PMC) / community procurement committee (CPC) will be offered the opportunity to earn recognition if they complete a checklist of items during the implementation phase of revenue sharing. The opportunity to earn recognition will be highlighted both during the training on the checklist and at least bi-weekly via reminder messages sent over the Bwindi Information Network. Control To prevent spillover, the control committee will be explicitly told that while no formal recognition will be offered for completing the checklist, it was designed to help manage the process of implementation to ensure revenue sharing projects are delivered as approved. As outcome variables, we will measure four variables (described in greater detail in the pre-analysis plan): number of checklist items completed, proportion of projects completed as approved, punishment in cooperation game (lab-in-field), and cheating in cooperation game (lab-in-field).

q19.value: 58 village committees as of registration; 18 add'l expected

q24.value: University of California, Santa Barbara Human Subjects Committee, Protocol Number 4-18-1018.

registration_responses.q1: Recognizing Good Governance: A Field Experiment in Uganda
registration_responses.q2: Mark Buntaine | Brigham Daniels | Tanner Bangerter
registration_responses.q5: We acknowledge the British Department for International Development for its support of this project.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: We theorize that fostering collective pride in good governance and providing positive recognition for local leaders who forego corruption and work diligently to manage local projects will decrease corruption in a national park revenue-sharing program in western Uganda. We will implement a randomized field experiment and linked ethnographic field study to test whether offering community recognition for the successful planning and implementation of revenue-sharing projects, along with associated radio announcements and public ceremonies that praise good governance, will result in more equitable planning and better delivery of revenue-sharing projects. Our study thus departs from the dominant lines of research on corruption that focus on detection and punishment and instead asks how civic expectations can be realigned to counteract corruption at the local level. We compare outcomes in villages that are made experimentally eligible for positive recognition to those villages that do not have eligibility for recognition.
registration_responses.q16: Our hypotheses are: Eligibility for recognition will cause committees to exert more effort and diligence in managing revenue sharing projects. Eligibility for recognition will increase the successful delivery of revenue-sharing projects. Eligibility for recognition will change residents’ norms and expectations to be less accepting of corruption and mismanagement. Eligibility for recognition will change committee members’ norms and beliefs about corruption and mismanagement. More detailed information can be found in our pre-analysis plan.
registration_responses.q17: We will use a randomized-control trial and accompanying ethnographic work of a research partner to test these hypotheses. As for the randomized control trial, the intervention is described below: Baseline All combination project management committee (PMC) / community procurement committee (CPC) will be provided with a checklist of procedures for considering bids for projects, evaluating the bids, and managing contractors. All combination committees will be trained in the procedures that would be required to earn excellence in revenue sharing. Intervention We propose that each combination project management committee (PMC) / community procurement committee (CPC) will be offered the opportunity to earn recognition if they complete a checklist of items during the implementation phase of revenue sharing. The opportunity to earn recognition will be highlighted both during the training on the checklist and at least bi-weekly via reminder messages sent over the Bwindi Information Network. Control To prevent spillover, the control committee will be explicitly told that while no formal recognition will be offered for completing the checklist, it was designed to help manage the process of implementation to ensure revenue sharing projects are delivered as approved. As outcome variables, we will measure four variables (described in greater detail in the pre-analysis plan): number of checklist items completed, proportion of projects completed as approved, punishment in cooperation game (lab-in-field), and cheating in cooperation game (lab-in-field).
registration_responses.q19: 58 village committees as of registration; 18 add'l expected
registration_responses.q24: University of California, Santa Barbara Human Subjects Committee, Protocol Number 4-18-1018.

attributes.title: Improving Local Service Provision Delivery in Eastern Congo: An Impact Evaluation of the Tuungane 2+ Interventions

q1.value: Improving Local Service Provision Delivery in Eastern Congo: An Impact Evaluation of the Tuungane 2+ Interventions

q2.value: Ann Laudati | Eric Mvukiyehe | Peter Van der Windt

q5.value: We have many people to thank for their input. We particularly thank Chloe Fernandez, Eustache Kuliumbwa and Jean Paul Zibika. From the IRC we thank Marie-France Guimond, Dana Olds and Guillaume Labrecque. From DFID we thank Helen Poulsen and Sarah Furrer.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) ranks 176th out of 188 in the UNDP’s 2016 Human Development Report, an annual ranking based on outcomes related to health, education, and income. Two decades of instability and conflict has led to the erosion of the state’s capacity to provide basic services. It has also weakened communities’ ability to be informed, to mobilize for collective action, and to monitor and influence frontline service providers. In Eastern Congo, the local governance system related to service delivery is thus largely unresponsive to the service delivery needs and priorities of the population. It is against this backdrop that in 2007, funded by UK’s DFID, the IRC and CARE International implemented the Tuungane program (“Tuungane” means “let’s unite” in Swahili). A first phase was implemented between 2007 and 2012. A second phase took place between 2012 and 2015. In 2015, Tuungane implemented an extension called Tuungane 2+ (or T2+) to ensure sustainability of the second phase. T2+ is implemented in 485 communities in three provinces of Eastern Congo: South Kivu, Haut Katanga and Tanganyika, reaching approximately one million beneficiaries. The components of the T2+ program include (a) capacity building of recently decentralized government units (so-called “ETDs”), (b) radio-related activities to support accountability and citizen participation in local governance, (c) a gender pilot aimed to improve women’s possibilities for effectively participating in, and influencing, community decision-making, and (d) grant projects in communities with a grant sizes of $8,990 in the health and education sectors and $2,358 for water and sanitation sectors. The goal of the Tuungane 2+ program is “to contribute to a local governance system that is responsive to the service delivery needs and priorities of the population, beyond the end of the program (IRC, 2014:4)” by ensuring the sustainability of the investment of the second phase of Tuungane. The Tuungane 2+ program takes the form of an experiment. The program’s grant projects component is implemented as a two-by-two factorial, in those communities that undertake projects in the health and education sector (339 communities). In Congo, day-to-day problem-solving and decision-making about local service delivery challenges are made by frontline service providers and user committee members during their monthly meetings. The interface space between these two actors is therefore of particular importance to local service delivery quality and related outcomes. However, this space may not be optimally utilized. Two sets of actors have access to and influence over the user committee and frontline service provider interface: service users (via their user committee) and line ministry staff (via frontline service providers). The interactions between these actors and user committees and frontline service providers are often irregular and of low quality. Thus, in addition to the main intervention that aims to strengthen ties between user committee members and frontline service providers, a randomly selected half of communities receive a set of additional activities to involve the users. Furthermore, a randomly selected half of communities receive a set of additional activities to involve the relevant line ministries in decision-making about service provision. This design thus allows us to causally test the impact of including users and/or the relevant line ministries in local service provision.

q16.value: H1: User involvement improves service provision environment H2: Line ministry involvement improves service provision environment H3: User and line ministry involvement leads to stronger outcomes than all other treatments

q17.value: The Tuungane 2+ program takes the form of an experiment. The program’s grant projects component is implemented as a two-by-two factorial, in those communities that undertake projects in the health and education sector (339 communities). In addition to the main intervention that aims to strengthen ties between user committee members and frontline service providers, a randomly selected half of communities receive a set of additional activities to involve the users. Furthermore, a randomly selected half of communities receive a set of additional activities to involve the relevant line ministries in decision-making about service provision. This design thus allows us to causally test the impact of including users and/or the relevant line ministries in local service provision. To measure "service provision" we make use of behavioral measures. For example, a set of enumerators will visit the user committee and service provider related to the sector that received the Tuungane project 10 days before the data collection. Enumerators will provide 22 brochures (11 to the user committee, 11 to the service provider) about the results of the Tuungane 2 impact evaluation. In addition, the user committee and service provider are given the task to draft a response to the international development community about the community’s needs and priorities. We leave the actors free how they want to write this document. We only provide a set of minimal guideline of what should be in the document. Importantly, in order not to raise expectations, we emphasize throughout that there is no future program planned for their village. As part of this activity, we aim to collect information about the quality of service delivery in the village. Do the user committee and service providers actively undertake activities (e.g. a community meeting) to spread information related to the Tuungane 2 program? Are the brochures spread throughout the village? Will the user committee and service provider work together to draft the response? Do the user committee and service providers actively undertake activities (e.g. a community meeting) to learn about the opinion of the villagers? Do villagers meet with the user committee or service providers to present their opinion? Do the needs and priorities mentioned in the document reflect those of the population?

registration_responses.q1: Improving Local Service Provision Delivery in Eastern Congo: An Impact Evaluation of the Tuungane 2+ Interventions
registration_responses.q2: Ann Laudati | Eric Mvukiyehe | Peter Van der Windt
registration_responses.q5: We have many people to thank for their input. We particularly thank Chloe Fernandez, Eustache Kuliumbwa and Jean Paul Zibika. From the IRC we thank Marie-France Guimond, Dana Olds and Guillaume Labrecque. From DFID we thank Helen Poulsen and Sarah Furrer.

Do villagers meet with the user committee or service providers to present their opinion? Do the needs and priorities mentioned in the document reflect those of the population?

attributes.title: Community Forest Monitoring and Awareness of Forest Use Rules in Uganda

q1.value: Community Forest Monitoring and Awareness of Forest Use Rules in Uganda

q2.value: Sabrina Eisenbarth | Louis Graham | Chaning Jang | Ariana Keyman | Anouk Rigterink

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Deforestation is an important contributor to world-wide greenhouse gas emissions: it is estimated that deforestation is responsible for 12% of anthropogenic carbon emissions (van der Werf et al., 2009). As such, reducing deforestation is considered one of the most cost-effective ways of reducing carbon emissions (Stern, 2006). Although the majority of the world’s forest area is administered by governments, a small but growing proportion of forest area is officially designated to be managed by Indigenous People and local communities. In the continent of Africa in particular, the share of forest area that is officially designated as such has increased from 3.9 per cent in 2002 to 5.8 per cent in 2013. These estimates do not include any formally government administered forest area that is de facto managed by local communities or Indigenous People because of weaknesses in enforcement of government legislation. The appeal of community forest management appears widespread, with “nearly every country in the world […] experimenting with some form of ‘Community Forestry’” (Edmonds, 2002). At the international level, the REDD+ (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation) aims to avoid deforestation. Communities are envisioned to contribute to measurement of carbon stocks embodied in forests as required by REDD+ Monitoring Reporting and Verification (MRV) (Government of Uganda, 2011; Kenya Forest Serivce, 2010). Deforestation is an important problem in Uganda, with some coining the deforestation rate in Uganda as the “highest in East Africa” (Banana, Bukenya, Arinaitwe, Birabwa, & Ssekindi, 2012). According to data from Global Forest Watch, 38 per cent of the land area in Uganda is covered by forest, and Ugandan forests are under a high risk of deforestation. The annual deforestation rate in Uganda amounted to 5.7% between 2001 and 2014. Deforestation and land use change contribute 37.6 percent to Uganda’s Greenhouse Gas emissions in 2011 (FAO data). Communities in Uganda play an important role both in forest management as well as in deforestation. Communities can (co)manage forests that are collectively privately owned, that are registered as community forests, or that are covered by a Collaborative Forest Management agreement (Government of Uganda, 2003). Correspondingly, one of Uganda’s National Forestry policy objectives linked to REDD+ is to “promote innovative approaches to community participation in forest management”. However, communities also engage in charcoal production, firewood harvesting, and livestock grazing, which are three out of the seven main drivers of deforestation as identified by Uganda’s REDD+ Readiness Preparation Proposal (Government of Uganda, 2011). The Ugandan REDD+ Readiness Preparation Proposal furthermore envisions that communities could be involved in forest monitoring under REDD+ MRV. It recognizes that communities, with support from NGOs have contributed to high-quality monitoring systems in other countries, such as Nepal. At the same time, it acknowledges that “community monitoring capacity is still relatively weak” (Government of Uganda, 2011).

q16.value: H1. Community monitoring increases forest stock H2. Community monitoring decreases forest use H3. Community monitoring affects household welfare (two-sided) H4. Community monitoring increases satisfaction with the state of the forest H5. Community monitoring increases knowledge about the state of the forest H6. Community monitoring increases the sense of stewardship over the forest H7. Community monitoring decreases uncertainty about the state of the forest and about forest use H8. Community monitoring increases participation in forest governing bodies H9. Community monitoring increases likelihood of sanctioning for violating forest use rules H10. Higher awareness of forest use rules decreases forest use H11. Higher awareness of forest use rules affects household welfare (two-sided) H12. Higher awareness of forest use rules increases knowledge of forest use rules H13. Higher awareness of forest use rules increases scrutiny of other forest users H14. Higher awareness of forest use rules increases the perceived likelihood of sanctioning for violating forest use rules H15. Higher awareness of forest use rules decreases household rating of their own forest conservation practices H16. Higher awareness of forest use rules changes satisfaction with forest use rules. H17. Higher awareness of forest use rules increases participation in forest governance bodies.

q19.value: 110 villages, 1100 households at baseline, 1200 households at endline

q24.value: SS4331 - Uganda Council for Science and Technology

attributes.title: Right preference of right-handers with an ability to resist anxiety: A pre-registered study

q1.value: Right preference of right-handers with an ability to resist anxiety: A pre-registered study

q2.value: Ayumi Ikeda | Haoqin Xu | Naoto Fuji | Siqi Zhu | Yuki Yamada

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The decision making of anxious people becomes susceptible to various factors. It is important to examine how the ability to resist anxiety is related to it. Bodily factors affect human spatial preference. Objects on the right side are liked by right-handed people. The ability to resist anxiety may be formed by this spatial preference. For example, positive emotion induced by the right-side object would be beneficial to improve mood of right-handers, resulting in cancelling anxiety.

q16.value: We will verify whether the left-right preference modulates highly anxious participant’s decision making. Our hypothesis is that participants with a greater ability to resist anxiety would choose an object at the side of dominant hand more frequently.

q17.value: Participants will be asked to select either the left or right card. The dependent variable is which card is chosen to measure the relation between the anxious state and body-based preferential side. Conditions are whether there is an anxious state inducer for participants. The experiment is within-subject design. The experiment is conducted on the web, we ask the participants to select cards three times. The card choice program displays the results as if the participants’ answers are always incorrect in the first two choices. We predict that the negative feedback will make participants feel anxious. The first choice without any stress is a control condition. The experimental condition is the third choice with stress by the negative feedbacks. We measure participants’ negative state using PANAS-Negative score (Positive and Negative Affect Schedule; Watson, Clark, & Tellegen, 1988). All participants will be assigned in the same conditions but they will be grouped based on the PANAS-Negative score.

registration_responses.q1: Right preference of right-handers with an ability to resist anxiety: A pre-registered study
registration_responses.q2: Ayumi Ikeda | Haoqin Xu | Naoto Fuji | Siqi Zhu | Yuki Yamada

attributes.title: Fostering Tolerance in a Religiously Divided Neighborhood. A Randomized Controlled Trial

q1.value: Fostering Tolerance in a Religiously Divided Neighborhood. A Randomized Controlled Trial

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: How can interreligious tolerance be fostered most effectively? While the causes of religious violence have received much attention in the academic literature, little is known about ways to counteract radical religious attitudes. The present project aims to fill this gap. Our focus is on Kenya's capital Nairobi. The city has, for years, suffered from significant tensions between Muslims and Christians. We partner with a local NGO to implement and evaluate educational forums---the Umoja Community Initiative---which aims to soothe tensions between Christians and Muslims. The program invites randomly selected men aged 18 to 35 in Eastleigh, a neighborhood notorious for religious violence. The fora vary along three dimensions, which allow us to better understand the mechanisms that link education to interreligious tolerance. First, we vary the topic of the classes, randomizing whether participants are exposed to religious or economic arguments for inter-religious tolerance or a placebo condition, which teaches participants about the environment. Second, we vary the composition of the group, randomizing whether Christians and Muslim attend the fora jointly or separately. Third, we vary the authority of the instructor, randomizing whether participants are taught by youth peers (horizontal authority) or religious clerics (vertical authority). This pre-analysis plan outlines our research design, honing in on our sampling, assignment, measurement and estimation strategy.

q16.value: The educational forums increase interreligious tolerance.

registration_responses.q1: Fostering Tolerance in a Religiously Divided Neighborhood. A Randomized Controlled Trial
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

We partner with a local NGO to implement and evaluate educational forums---the Umoja Community Initiative---which aims to soothe tensions between Christians and Muslims. The program invites randomly selected men aged 18 to 35 in Eastleigh, a neighborhood notorious for religious violence. The fora vary along three dimensions, which allow us to better understand the mechanisms that link education to interreligious tolerance. First, we vary the topic of the classes, randomizing whether participants are exposed to religious or economic arguments for inter-religious tolerance or a placebo condition, which teaches participants about the environment. Second, we vary the composition of the group, randomizing whether Christians and Muslim attend the fora jointly or separately. Third, we vary the authority of the instructor, randomizing whether participants are taught by youth peers (horizontal authority) or religious clerics (vertical authority). This pre-analysis plan outlines our research design, honing in on our sampling, assignment, measurement and estimation strategy.
registration_responses.q16: The educational forums increase interreligious tolerance.

attributes.title: The Effects of DACA on Pregnancy Outcomes in California

q1.value: The Effects of DACA on Pregnancy Outcomes in California

q2.value: Jacqueline Torres | Rita Hamad | Emanuel Alcala | Amber Costantino | Tania Pacheco-Werner | Michael Hotard | Duncan Lawrence | Jens Hainmueller

q5.value: This study is partially supported by the California Preterm Birth Initiative

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The DACA program was passed by Executive Order on June 15, 2012. DACA provided temporary protection against deportation and work permits for individuals who were undocumented, had arrived in the US at < 16 years of age, and were younger than 31 years of age on June 15, 2012. To be DACA-eligible, individuals additionally had to have resided in the US since 2007, be enrolled in school or hold a GED, and have never been convicted of a felony or > 3 misdemeanors. The fate of the DACA program is currently under discussion, making this research very pertinent to ongoing policymaking. Quasi-experimental and other observational research has uncovered evidence of positive effects of DACA on the psychological wellbeing of recipients.1,2 Quasi-experimental research has also demonstrated causal effects of DACA on better mental health for the children of recipients.3 Potential pathways linking DACA to improved health include its positive effects on employment outcomes,4 as well as reductions in worry about deportation. Worry about deportation, as with other chronic stressors, may have negative consequences on multiple body systems,5 and may result in foregoing necessary medical care. No research, to our knowledge, has examined the relationship between DACA and birth outcomes, including preterm birth. Scholars have linked immigration-related stressors (e.g. prenatal exposure to immigration raids, the passage of restrictive immigration policies) to birth outcomes.6,7 In addition, researchers have uncovered improvements in prenatal care and birth outcomes as the result of an inclusive policy that expanded healthcare access for pregnant undocumented women.8

q16.value: We will quantify the effect of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) immigration policy on the composition of births and birth outcomes among infants born to likely eligible mothers as compared to infants born to demographically similar mothers who would have been ineligible based on date of birth.

q17.value: We propose to estimate the effects of DACA on pregnancy outcomes for likely DACA-eligible women and their infants in California, using California birth records data. We propose to use a quasi-experimental strategy that will allow us to evaluate the effects of DACA. We note, however, that power calculations using simulated data suggests that we will not be sufficiently powered to detect small effects of DACA using California birth records alone – and may need to expand to a national analysis. The ideal design for this study would follow the regression discontinuity approach employed by Hainmueller et al3 and compare differences in birth outcomes after DACA passage for foreign-born women just above/below the birthdate cutoff (June 19, 1981). Nevertheless, power calculations using simulated data indicate that we would be only powered to detect unrealistically large (e.g. 1 standard deviation) with this strategy, in part because of the relatively low uptake of DACA among women who would be classified as DACA recipients. We therefore propose to use a difference-in-differences (DID) design, a quasi-experimental technique well suited to examining the effects of policies among population subgroups while adjusting for secular trends in a “control” group of similar individuals. In particular, we will compare overall birth outcomes both before and after the passage of DACA among likely DACA-eligible women, “differencing out” secular trends among women who are otherwise demographically similar (e.g. non-US born) but are ineligible because they missed the birthdate cut-off. In this approach, women will be identified as likely eligible or ineligible based on demographic characteristics (e.g. foreign-born, maternal ethnicity, educational characteristics, area of residence), age (i.e. < 31 years of age versus > 31 before June 15, 2012), and payment source listed in the birth record (if available). While the DID design is better powered, it comes with assumptions that trends in outcomes for treatment and control groups would otherwise be similar if it were not for DACA passage/implementation and that DACA implementation would not contribute to changes in the composition of births (e.g. by maternal characteristics) for treatment or control groups. These assumptions may be unrealistic, particularly given that DACA was linked to improved labor market and economic outcomes – both of which may have influenced fertility.9 To our knowledge, one study has demonstrated reduced fertility among adolescent girls/young women after DACA implementation.9 While the parallel trends assumption cannot be directly tested, we will evaluate whether trends in each of the birth outcomes (listed below) looked similar at 1 and 2 years pre-DACA passage for treatment and control groups using California birth records. We will additionally evaluate the effect of DACA on the composition of births (e.g. by maternal age, educational attainment, marital status, male-to-female infant sex ratio). Finally, we will evaluate effects of DACA on fertility using appropriate denominators from the American Community Survey. If assumptions appear to be met, we will move forward with evaluating the effects of DACA on the birth outcomes listed below. In either case, we will report on any effects of DACA on the composition of births.

q19.value: Sample size is determined by the number of births in California birth certificate data that meet eligibility criteria

q23.value: Use of California birth certificate data by CSU Fresno/Central Valley Health Policy Institute colleagues has been approved by the CSU Fresno IRB.

registration_responses.q1: The Effects of DACA on Pregnancy Outcomes in California
registration_responses.q2: Jacqueline Torres | Rita Hamad | Emanuel Alcala | Amber Costantino | Tania Pacheco-Werner | Michael Hotard | Duncan Lawrence | Jens Hainmueller
registration_responses.q5: This study is partially supported by the California Preterm Birth Initiative
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data
registration_responses.q15: The DACA program was passed by Executive Order on June 15, 2012. DACA provided temporary protection against deportation and work permits for individuals who were undocumented, had arrived in the US at < 16 years of age, and were younger than 31 years of age on June 15, 2012. To be DACA-eligible, individuals additionally had to have resided in the US since 2007, be enrolled in school or hold a GED, and have never been convicted of a felony or > 3 misdemeanors. The fate of the DACA program is currently under discussion, making this research very pertinent to ongoing policymaking. Quasi-experimental and other observational research has uncovered evidence of positive effects of DACA on the psychological wellbeing of recipients.1,2 Quasi-experimental research has also demonstrated causal effects of DACA on better mental health for the children of recipients.3 Potential pathways linking DACA to improved health include its positive effects on employment outcomes,4 as well as reductions in worry about deportation. Worry about deportation, as with other chronic stressors, may have negative consequences on multiple body systems,5 and may result in foregoing necessary medical care. No research, to our knowledge, has examined the relationship between DACA and birth outcomes, including preterm birth. Scholars have linked immigration-related stressors (e.g. prenatal exposure to immigration raids, the passage of restrictive immigration policies) to birth outcomes.6,7 In addition, researchers have uncovered improvements in prenatal care and birth outcomes as the result of an inclusive policy that expanded healthcare access for pregnant undocumented women.8
registration_responses.q16: We will quantify the effect of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) immigration policy on the composition of births and birth outcomes among infants born to likely eligible mothers as compared to infants born to demographically similar mothers who would have been ineligible based on date of birth.
registration_responses.q17: We propose to estimate the effects of DACA on pregnancy outcomes for likely DACA-eligible women and their infants in California, using California birth records data. We propose to use a quasi-experimental strategy that will allow us to evaluate the effects of DACA. We note, however, that power calculations using simulated data suggests that we will not be sufficiently powered to detect small effects of DACA using California birth records alone – and may need to expand to a national analysis. The ideal design for this study would follow the regression discontinuity approach employed by Hainmueller et al3 and compare differences in birth outcomes after DACA passage for foreign-born women just above/below the birthdate cutoff (June 19, 1981). Nevertheless, power calculations using simulated data indicate that we would be only powered to detect unrealistically large (e.g. 1 standard deviation) with this strategy, in part because of the relatively low uptake of DACA among women who would be classified as DACA recipients. We therefore propose to use a difference-in-differences (DID) design, a quasi-experimental technique well suited to examining the effects of policies among population subgroups while adjusting for secular trends in a “control” group of similar individuals. In particular, we will compare overall birth outcomes both before and after the passage of DACA among likely DACA-eligible women, “differencing out” secular trends among women who are otherwise demographically similar (e.g. non-US born) but are ineligible because they missed the birthdate cut-off. In this approach, women will be identified as likely eligible or ineligible based on demographic characteristics (e.g. foreign-born, maternal ethnicity, educational characteristics, area of residence), age (i.e. < 31 years of age versus > 31 before June 15, 2012), and payment source listed in the birth record (if available). While the DID design is better powered, it comes with assumptions that trends in outcomes for treatment and control groups would otherwise be similar if it were not for DACA passage/implementation and that DACA implementation would not contribute to changes in the composition of births (e.g. by maternal characteristics) for treatment or control groups. These assumptions may be unrealistic, particularly given that DACA was linked to improved labor market and economic outcomes – both of which may have influenced fertility.9 To our knowledge, one study has demonstrated reduced fertility among adolescent girls/young women after DACA implementation.9 While the parallel trends assumption cannot be directly tested, we will evaluate whether trends in each of the birth outcomes (listed below) looked similar at 1 and 2 years pre-DACA passage for treatment and control groups using California birth records. We will additionally evaluate the effect of DACA on the composition of births (e.g. by maternal age, educational attainment, marital status, male-to-female infant sex ratio). Finally, we will evaluate effects of DACA on fertility using appropriate denominators from the American Community Survey. If assumptions appear to be met, we will move forward with evaluating the effects of DACA on the birth outcomes listed below. In either case, we will report on any effects of DACA on the composition of births.
